subject: Art
title: Color Gamut
description: The range of colors a device or medium can reproduce.

hook.text: Your eye can see millions of colors. Your screen can show most of them. Your printer? Maybe half. Every device has a limit ‚Äî a color gamut ‚Äî the range of colors it can reproduce.

buildup.text: Gamut is visualized as a shape in color space. sRGB (standard screens) is a triangle. Adobe RGB is a larger triangle. CMYK is a smaller, differently-shaped region. The human eye's gamut dwarfs them all.

discovery.text: When a color falls outside a device's gamut, it gets 'clipped' to the nearest reproducible color. That electric neon green on screen? It becomes a duller green in print. That's gamut clipping.

twist.text: Wide-gamut monitors (P3, Adobe RGB) can display more colors than sRGB monitors. But if your audience uses sRGB screens, those extra colors won't be seen. Design for your audience's gamut.

climax.text: Soft-proofing: previewing how your colors will look in a different gamut before output. Every professional designer does this to avoid unpleasant surprises at the printer.

punchline.text: Your art can only be as colorful as the medium allows. Know the gamut, avoid the surprises.

quiz.question: What happens when a color falls outside a device's color gamut?
options: It gets clipped to the nearest reproducible color
